JUDGMENT
VIVIER JA:
The eight appellants are all industrial councils registered or deemed
to have been registered as such under the Labour Relations Act 28 of 1956
("the LRA"), each with regional jurisdiction over different geographical
areas of the building industry in
South Africa
. Although the LRA has now
been repealed by the
Labour Relations Act 66 of 1995
it was common cause
that this case must be decided as if the latter Act had not been passed. The
respondent is an industrial council which is deemed under sec 9(9) of the
Legal Succession to the South African Transport Services Act 9 of 1989
("the Act") to have been registered as such under the LRA. According to
the respondent's registration certificate issued by the industrial registrar on
2 October 1991 it was registered in respect of -

applicants: Industrial Council for the Building Industry (Western Province)
Industrial Council for the Building Industry, Bloemfontein

Building Industrial Council, North and West Roland
Industrial Council for the Building Industry, Kimberley

sections.facts: Several regional building‑industry industrial councils (the appellants) challenged the registration and jurisdiction of the Transnet Industrial Council (the respondent). All appellants were registered or deemed registered under the Labour Relations Act 28 of 1956 (LRA) and each held jurisdiction over a distinct geographical area of the building industry. The respondent was deemed registered under section 9(9) of the South African Transport Services Act 9 of 1989. Although the LRA had been repealed by the Labour Relations Act 66 of 1995, the court was required to decide the matter as if the repeal had not occurred.
sections.issues: 1. Whether the Transnet Industrial Council was validly registered under the LRA despite the later repeal of that Act. 2. Whether the appellants, as regional building‑industry councils, had standing to contest the respondent’s registration and jurisdiction. 3. How the statutory provisions of the LRA and the Transport Services Act should be interpreted in light of the repeal.
sections.principles: The court applied the principle that legislation repealed after a registration does not invalidate a registration that was effective under the earlier law. Section 9(9) of the Transport Services Act was analysed to confirm the respondent’s deemed registration. The continuity of rights and obligations accrued under the LRA was upheld, and the court affirmed that disputes must be resolved as if the later Act had not been enacted, consistent with statutory interpretation rules favouring the protection of vested rights.
sections.application: The court examined the registration certificate issued to the respondent on 2 October 1991 and found it complied with the requirements of the LRA as in force at that time. It held that the repeal of the LRA by the 1995 Act did not retrospectively affect the respondent’s status. The appellants’ claim of exclusive regional jurisdiction was rejected because the respondent’s registration covered a distinct sector (transport) and did not infringe upon the building‑industry councils’ domains.
sections.conclusion: The Supreme Court of Appeal dismissed the appeals of the building‑industry councils. It confirmed that the Transnet Industrial Council was duly registered and possessed the requisite jurisdiction, and that the repeal of the LRA did not invalidate its registration.
